Award.AbstractNarration:
The research funded by the award will be directed towards several closely related questions and activities. A first part of the project is to build the theory of algebraic stacks from scratch, with the goal of writing foundations for algebraic stacks with a minimal amount of assumptions on the base scheme, no separation axioms for algebraic spaces, and no separation axioms for algebraic stacks. This will be continually documented online in the stacks project, see http://math.columbia.edu/algebraic_geometry/stacks-git. Many algebraic stacks are quotient stacks, but this is not always the case. A second component of the project involves the question of whether every algebraic stack is always etale locally a quotient stack. This is related to the question of whether the cohomological Brauer group and the classical Brauer group coincide for separated smooth algebraic spaces over a field. This leads into other questions, especially the relation between period and index for Brauer classes. A third part of the project is to see whether there exists a natural degree map on the group of zero cycles on a GIT-stack. And finally, the project includes a fourth part aimed at studying moduli of stacky curves, which is a natural explicit example of a higher algebraic stack. Throughout the PI will moderate the stacks project mentioned above.

A question that has long fascinated physicists and philosophers is:
What is space? For a mathematician a 3-dimensional manifold seems a good first approximation to space. After learning about special relativity a four dimensional space with a Lorentz metric seems closer. After learning about the standard model it seems that space comes endowed with certain vector bundles. And so on. In algebraic geometry students are taught early on that there are many different spaces, and that in fact the collection of all spaces forms itself some kind of space. A famous example is the moduli space of curves of genus g (Riemann surfaces) which is used by physicists in string theory. In a fundamental paper on moduli of curves in algebraic geometry, Deligne and Mumford pointed out that the space of curves has additional structure in that its points come endowed with certain finite groups (namely the automorphism groups of the corresponding curves). They coined the phrase "algebraic stack" to denote this type of space. It turns out that the language of algebraic stacks is an extremely useful tool in studying very classical objects such as vector bundles on curves and surfaces, moduli of elliptic curves and abelian varieties, etc, etc. The project will partly develop the foundations of algebraic stacks in a very general setting, and partly find new properties of these spaces, such as whether the finite groups attached to the points of an algebraic stack all in some natural way are contained in a single bigger group.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the work done under the award this final report is on is the mathematics behind the Stacks project 

The Stacks project is an open source textbook and reference work on algebraic stacks and the algebraic geometry needed to define them. The Stacks project aims to build up enough basic algebraic geometry as foundations for algebraic stacks. This implies a good deal of theory on commutative algebra, schemes, varieties, algebraic spaces, has to be developed en route. The Stacks project is a bit like an open source software development project; it has a maintainer (Aise Johan de Jong for the duration of the award) who accepts changes etc. proposed by contributors. Although everyone is encouraged to participate it is not a wiki. The Stacks project is meant to be read online. This means arguments can be made in full as the authors do not have to worry about length (as in usual publications). Moreover, with hyperlinks it is possible to quickly browse through the chapters to find the lemmas, theorems, etc. that a given result depends on.

As part of the work done under the award we have found the overall setup of the Stacks project to be quite efficient for building theory quickly. Once the initial foundational material is correctly laid out, one can rather quickly head in a given direction. Although some papers and preprints already reference the Stacks project, over time we expect more and more researchers in the field of algebraic geometry to start using the Stacks project as a reference for foundational results not only on algebraic stacks and algebraic spaces, but also for schemes and commutative algebra. This will partly be the case because some results can only be found in the Stacks project. Namely, the Stacks project covers certain topics in a level of generality not found elsewhere (this is a consequence of it being a project into the foundations of algebraic geometry and in particular algebraic stacks). Occasionally because of contributions proving new results (not just generalizations of known results). Another factor, which is by design also, is that the Stacks project is a convenient source of references for researchers: it is online and comes with a search function.

Some specific mathematical outcomes in the work done under this award are: a theory of adequate modules which can be used as a substitute of quasi-coherent modules on algebraic stacks, algebraic spaces are fpqc sheaves (Ofer Gabber), a version of Artin's theorem on representability of algebraic stacks using naive cotangent complexes, a good description of constructible \'etale sheaves, a detailed discussion of the foundations of pro-\'etale cohomology, an account of Popescu's theorem, a generalization of Artin's theorem on dilatations, and more.

As a fun application of the Stacks project, there is a simple way to see the logical interdependencies of the mathematical results in the project. An example graphical representation is the image included in this report.
